{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2988251,"name":"Roger","username":"RogerMCT","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rogermct/{size}/265955_2.png","created_at":"2022-01-10T17:14:50.745Z","cooked":"

Looking for verification on rule R624.
If the cables are covered for manageability (wrapped) but are colored all the way through. Is that OK?
Example:

amazon.com

Amazon.com: Voltive 12/2 Speaker Wire - 12 AWG/Gauge 2 Conductor - UL Listed in...

Performance & SpecsWe build wire right: no sub-standard materials and no reduced conductor or jacket thickness. In short, this is the wire we would install in our own homes:- 12 gauge, 2 conductor speaker cable (also...

No one here can give an official answer, so definitely ask through Q&A when it opens.

In my opinion, this should be considered legal as the wires are “color-coded along their entire length from the manufacturer”. The outer sleeving is a wire management convenience, just like zip cord bonding is.

We have used sleeved wire for many years, as long as each conductor in the sleeve is the correct color (red, black, etc) it shouldn’t be an issue.

Jacketed wire was legal in the past and I don’t see why that would change. Putting sleeves over your wires has also been acceptable in the past.
